summary: This is an FBI News Briefing dated July 29, 2020, summarizing major news stories from that day. It covers a wide range of topics including Attorney General William Barr's contentious testimony before the House Judiciary Committee, protests in Portland and other cities, various criminal investigations, and international news. A small section notes federal prosecutors opposing Ghislaine Maxwell's effort to name Jeffrey Epstein's victims.

persons.name: William Barr
persons.role: Attorney General of the United States
persons.context: Testified before the House Judiciary Committee, defending federal actions against protests, the decision to drop charges against Michael Flynn, and his handling of the Roger Stone case.

persons.name: Jerrold Nadler
persons.context: Chaired the hearing with AG Barr, accused Barr of distorting the Justice Department for President Trump's political agenda.

persons.name: Jim Jordan
persons.context: Ranking member of the House Judiciary Committee, defended Barr and criticized the Russia probe, aired a video contrasting media coverage with violent protest footage.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Mentioned in a brief item where federal prosecutors opposed her legal team's effort to name underage girls she is accused of grooming for Jeffrey Epstein.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Mentioned as the financier for whom Ghislaine Maxwell allegedly groomed underage victims.

persons.name: Nancy Pelosi
persons.context: Criticized by Barr for comparing federal officers in Portland to Nazi stormtroopers; she called Barr's testimony 'despicable'.

persons.name: Cedric Richmond
persons.context: Accused Barr and his predecessors (Sessions, Whitaker) of systemic racism for not bringing black people into their top staff.

persons.name: Mike Pence
persons.role: Vice President of the United States
persons.context: Criticized Democrats for the Barr hearing, said violence in Portland 'has got to stop', and credited Trump for vaccine progress.

persons.name: John Bash
persons.role: U.S. Attorney for the Western District of Texas
persons.context: Revealed by Barr to be investigating a 'high number of unmaskings' during the Obama administration, related to Michael Flynn.

persons.name: Michael Flynn
persons.context: Barr defended the DOJ's decision to drop charges against him; unmasking of his identity is under investigation.

persons.name: Roger Stone
persons.context: Barr defended his intervention to recommend a shorter prison sentence for Stone, a Trump associate.

persons.name: Hank Johnson
persons.context: Sparred with Barr over the Roger Stone sentencing during the hearing.

persons.name: Kayleigh McEnany
persons.context: Said Democrats' criticism of Barr is rooted in his probe of 'Russia-gate'.

persons.name: Kerri Kupec
persons.context: Commented on Fox News that Democrats at the Barr hearing refused to let him answer questions.

persons.name: Steny Hoyer
persons.context: Denied Democrats support violent rioters and appeared to liken Trump to fascists.

persons.name: Alex Rossmiller
persons.context: Filed opposition to Ghislaine Maxwell's effort to name Epstein victims, calling the argument 'absurd'.

connections.description: Nadler, as committee chair, led Democratic accusations against Barr for politicizing the DOJ; Barr defended his actions in a contentious hearing.
Jordan, the ranking Republican, defended Barr and the hearing, criticizing the Democratic-led Russia investigation.
Maxwell is accused of grooming underage girls for sexual abuse by financier Jeffrey Epstein.
Barr defended the DOJ's decision to drop the prosecution of former National Security Advisor Michael Flynn.
Barr intervened to recommend a shorter prison sentence for Trump associate Roger Stone, which he defended during the hearing.
Barr appointed U.S. Attorney John Bash to investigate 'unmasking' requests related to Michael Flynn during the Obama administration.

events.title: Barr Testifies Before House Judiciary Committee
events.description: Attorney General William Barr gave contentious testimony before the House Judiciary Committee, defending federal actions in Portland, the dropping of charges against Michael Flynn, and his intervention in the Roger Stone case.

events.title: Prosecutors Oppose Maxwell Naming Victims
events.description: Federal prosecutors filed opposition to Ghislaine Maxwell's effort to publicly name the underage girls she is accused of grooming for Jeffrey Epstein, arguing to maintain victim anonymity.

events.title: Portland Protests Continue
events.description: Violent protests continued at the federal courthouse in Portland, Oregon, with protesters attacking the building and burning an American flag. Federal agents responded with tear gas and flash bangs.

keyFacts: Attorney General William Barr had a heated testimony before the House Judiciary Committee on July 28, 2020, defending his actions on protests, Michael Flynn, and Roger Stone.
Federal prosecutors opposed Ghislaine Maxwell's legal effort to name the underage victims she allegedly groomed for Jeffrey Epstein, seeking to protect their anonymity.
Barr revealed he had appointed U.S. Attorney John Bash to investigate 'unmasking' requests related to Michael Flynn during the Obama administration.
The FBI News Briefing is a daily summary of major news stories, indicating the document itself is not a primary investigative record but a secondary compilation.
The document covers a vast array of topics beyond the Epstein case, with the Maxwell/Epstein item being a single, brief entry among many.
